perturbation.original_text: In the event of a conflict between the terms of this Agreement Summary and the General Provisions, the terms of the General Provisions shall prevail.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event of a conflict between the terms of this Agreement Summary and the General Provisions, the terms of this Agreement Summary shall prevail unless explicitly stated otherwise in the General Provisions.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts the original hierarchy, where the General Provisions always took precedence. Now, the Agreement Summary prevails unless the General Provisions explicitly state otherwise, creating uncertainty about which section controls in case of a conflict.

perturbation.original_text: SDBF agrees to indemnify, protect, defend, and hold harmless Sponsor,  its affiliates, predecessors and successors, owners, agents, partners, officials, employees and representatives (collectively, the "Sponsor Parties") from and against any and all actions, demands, liabilities, losses, claims, damages, costs or expenses, including without limitation court costs and attorneys' fees (collectively, the "Claims"), arising from the negligence or willful misconduct of SDBF or any of its affiliates, predecessors and successors, owners, agents, partners, officials, employees or representatives.
perturbation.changed_text: SDBF agrees to indemnify, protect, defend, and hold harmless Sponsor,  its affiliates, predecessors and successors, owners, agents, partners, officials, employees and representatives (collectively, the "Sponsor Parties") from and against any and all actions, demands, liabilities, losses, claims, damages, costs or expenses, including without limitation court costs and attorneys' fees (collectively, the "Claims"), arising from the gross negligence or willful misconduct of SDBF or any of its affiliates, predecessors and successors, owners, agents, partners, officials, employees or representatives. However, SDBF's indemnification obligations shall be capped at $10,000 per incident.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause states SDBF will indemnify Sponsor for any claims arising from SDBF's negligence or willful misconduct. The modification changes "negligence" to "gross negligence" which requires a higher degree of fault to trigger indemnification, which makes it more challenging for the Sponsor to be fully protected, but then contradicts by adding a cap of $10,000 per incident. The original text promised full indemnification, meaning no limit on the amount for costs or expenses arising from a claim; the edited statement now places a limit on the amount they will protect the Sponsor from.

perturbation.original_text: Except as provided in Section 22, no party shall assign this Agreement without the prior written approval of the other party, provided, however, that without obtaining such prior written approval, (a) SDBF may assign this Agreement to a transferee of the Padres' MLB franchise or to an affiliate of the Padres, and (b) Sponsor may assign this Agreement to an affiliate of Sponsor, provided that Sponsor shall continue to be obligated to SDBF for performance of Sponsor's obligations hereunder.
perturbation.changed_text: Except as provided in Section 22, no party shall assign this Agreement without the prior written approval of the other party. Notwithstanding the foregoing, either party may freely assign this agreement to any entity that acquires all or substantially all of its assets. However, such assignment shall not relieve the assigning party of its obligations under this Agreement unless the other party provides written consent.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies conditions under which assignment is permitted without prior approval, outlining certain entities and maintaining Sponsor's obligations. The modified text first restates the original provision, then creates a carve-out allowing for free assignment upon acquisition of assets, but then contradicts this by stating the assigning party remains obligated unless written consent is obtained. This introduces uncertainty about when assignment is truly permissible and whether the assigning party is relieved of its obligations, causing uncertainty about the obligations and rights of each party.
